Etymology. The specific name refers to thetype locality; adjective.

Diagnosis. This species resemblesAnimaliaArachnidaAraneaePholcidaePholcusabstrususspeciesYao & Li, 2012P.abstrususYao & Li, 2012 (seeYao & Li 2012: 8, figs 1–4) with male chelicerae (Fig. 16 D), bulbal apophyses (Fig. 16 C) and epigynum (Fig. 16 A) but can be distinguished by the short apophysis on the male pedipalpal trochanter (Figs 15 A–B), by the absence of sclerotized dorsal apophyses distally on the procursus (Figs 15 C–D), by the weakly protruding medially vulval anterior arch (Fig. 16 B) and by the rounded vulval pore plates (Fig. 16 B).

Description. Male (holotype): Total length 5.31 (5.78 with clypeus), carapace 1.40 long, 1.68 wide, opisthosoma 3.91 long, 1.76 wide. Leg I missing, leg II: 31.59 (8.28 + 0.77 + 8.16 + 12.75 + 1.63), leg III: 22.21 (6.56 + 0.63 + 5.58 + 8.24 + 1.20), leg IV: 28.95 (8.46 + 0.63 + 7.37 + 11.05 + 1.44). Distance PME-PME 0.44; diameter PME 0.14; distance PME-ALE 0.03; distance AME-AME 0.06; diameter AME 0.06. Sternum wider than long (1.02/0.88). Habitus as inFigs 16 E–F. Carapace yellowish, with brown marks extending to ocular area; ocular area yellowish with brown marks; sternum brown. Legs yellowish, distal parts of tibiae whitish, darker rings absent. Opisthosoma yellowish, with small spots dorsally. Ocular area elevated; each eye triad strongly elevated (as inAnimaliaArachnidaAraneaePholcidaePholcusyanjinensisspeciesP. yanjinensis sp. nov., cf.Fig. 27 A). Thoracic furrow absent. Chelicerae as inFig. 16 D, with a pair of proximolateral apophyses, a pair of black distal apophyses, and a pair of frontal apophyses. Pedipalps as inFigs 15 A–B; trochanter with a short ventral apophysis; femur with a dorsal apophysis proximally and a distinct ventral ridge; tibia with a projection prolaterally; procursus simple proximally but complex and unsclerotized distally, with a prolatero-dorsal spine (arrow inFig. 15 D); uncus with a scaly edge; appendix curved, with a branch medially; embolus weakly sclerotized. Legs with short vertical setae on tibiae, metatarsi and tarsi; without spines and curved setae.

Female: Similar to male, habitus as inFigs 16 G–H. Total length 5.12 (5.25 with clypeus), carapace 1.28 long, 1.34 wide, opisthosoma 3.84 long, 1.70 wide; tibia I: 8.51; tibia I L/d: 66. Distance PME-PME 0.23; diameter PME 0.13; distance PME-ALE 0.03; distance AME-AME 0.05; diameter AME 0.06. Sternum wider than long (0.88/ 0.75). Eye triads closer together, less elevated. Epigynum (Fig. 16 A) with a knob. Vulva (Fig. 16 B) with a straight sclerotized anterior arch and two rounded pore plates.
Natural History. The species was found on the wall in the entrance zone of the cave.
